pros: Best time to work in full time
cons: Giving best salary which could better

pros: BENEFITS and staff salaries are exceptional.
cons: NO LEADERSHIP and accountability is available.

review_title: Great mission, motivated people, so-so professional appeal
pros: SBP fosters relationships, incorporates big ideas, and fulfills its mission of "shrinking the time between disaster and recovery." While I was there, first as an AmeriCorps project lead then as a staff member, I was able to rise quickly and make big impact in an organization that is super malleable and gung-ho about disaster recovery. Rebuilding homes is a huge part of the process and SBP does this so, so well.
cons: Very few staff have professional experience as contractors, engineers, or construction workers before SBP, which inhibits its ability to incorporate emerging construction technologies and ramp up efficiency. SBP also has very little data management capacity, analytical might, or professional development tracks in case management. It is an office of do-gooders who do good! But at the expense of having high quality folks leave the organization after a couple years or less.

review_title: They Will Sacrifice You To Keep Their Story
job_title: Project Lead in New Orleans, LA
pros: There was space to develop your position and you could acquire a lot of skills without previous experience.
cons: I really struggled with the values of SBP. They did not live up to their alleged goals and values. There was little input from community members, yet our work was called "community development." It seemed like there was more time and effort into tell donors what our values were than there was effort to live up to them. When Americorps members advocated for safety practices surrounding Covid we were pretty viciously shut down by the upper level administration. There are people in this agency who care, but the system in place at SBP is not looking to protect Americorp members. I struggle to believe they are more invested in doing right by the community than they are invested in doing right by themselves and how they want people to see them to be. I felt unsupported, dismissed and belittled by my time with SPB. They also misled many of us on what our position was and the opportunities we would have. This is a good position if you are looking to find a foothold in Nola or if you want to get construction skills. If you're looking to learn how to live in community and build a better world, this is not the place you will learn those skills. I was very disappointed by my professional experience here.

pros: Everyone at SBP is just an A+ human. Everyone radiates the kindest and most supportive energy.
cons: The only downside I could think of is salary - because it is a non-profit, you will never be making an outrageous amount of money. However, they compensate employees fairly.

review_title: Great starting place for former AmC
pros: Great benefits, culture, and support within the organization
cons: Vague work descriptions. Employees can end up wearing a lot of hats which may or may not be suitable for each individual.

job_title: Volunteer Coordinator in San Juan, PR
pros: SBP is full of amazing, passionate people genuinely looking to make a difference.
cons: AmeriCorps pay is low but education award is a plus.

job_title: Logistics Coordinator in San Juan, PR
pros: you get to help communities
cons:
gossip
favoritism
toxic relations 
lack of management
some are left out and bullied because of their diversity

pros: The team at SBP is great. Respectful and hard working but also take time to get to know each other. Our work helps low income families recover from disasters and I like that we stay to help for many years.
cons: The work is fast paced especially when we activate for disasters.

pros: Great team environment. Rewarding work rebuilding homes for families.
cons: Salaries are low as compared to other nonprofits

pros: Flexible, caring, understanding, innovative, etc.
cons: No cons are currently present

job_title: Director of Case Management in Columbia, SC
pros: SBP's mission provide tools to areas impacted by Disaster Recovery.
cons: There are no Cons I can refer to.

pros: Good job for starting in humanitarian and relief projects.
cons: Is very short-term and does not give much possibility for long run jobs.

pros: Best work environment of any NGO I’ve worked for
cons: Rough work life balance but worth it

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:
- meet a lot of very nice and interesting people who have the potential of being friends for life
- low-stress environment relatively
- learn a lot of new skills, even if it sometimes is trial by error
- Lower level management is awesome and really get what it's like to be out there in the field due to their experience
- I did my service during COVID and I think they did a pretty good job all things considered
cons:
- Not especially safe, even for a construction site. Make sure to wear headphones or noise blockers of some kind because nobody protects their ears and many people, including myself, ended up losing some hearing ability
- Management treats Americorps members like children, yes many of them are young, but I was treated like more of an adult as a Jr camp counselor when I was 16
- Pay is awful, basically, I didn't have any extra money beyond food, rent, and other essentials. But it is a term of service so it is what it is. You know what you are signing up for.
- The recruitment process for Americorps positions was a little bizarre to me. Some of the people there very clearly had no interest in the job or working in a construction site or were extremely difficult to work with. I don't get how a few people got hired to be honest. No knock against them but it just made no sense for them to work in construction at a nonprofit I'm sure they are great at another job though.
- upper management is awful. AWFUL. Didn't care at all about the Americorps members, were fake, and as far as I can tell create a toxic work environment
-I really didn't like how whenever we did a meeting we had to start off with an icebreaker I get how it makes sense the first time for new people or for volunteers but I mean come on. It's just a little childish in my opinion. I don't need to know my boss's boss's assistant's favorite ice cream flavor

pros: At it's heart, the mission is good. Coworkers at the same management level were truly the saving grace of SBP.
cons:
- TOXIC management
- overworked and severly underpaid employees
- no work life balance
- while reports of the organization praise how much work they've done, management often sits on decisions and funds and lets months pass before doing anything
- management often throws their employees under the bus 
- CEO is horrible, condescending, rude, big-headed. COO is nice though
- management likes to "dig deeper" but don't listen

pros: Very rewarding and important work. Great culture.
cons: Questionable handling of a harassment complaint

pros: Awesome people and mission centric
cons: Lots of pressure and can be stressful

pros: Minimal support provided to construction employees
cons:
Poor management 
No support to employees

pros: There are no pros for this org
cons: Over worked and underpaid, most employees were working two to three jobs and only getting paid for one, abusive CEO, awful management, cut corners in order to appear as if they were meeting goals, absolutely no training for new employees besides a 2 day orientation that involved watching videos. Their slogan was “being here for 1 month is like being at another company for 6 months”. They expected you to be caught up with 6 months of experience in one month then gave you corrective action when you couldn’t meet unattainable goals. They made HR managers try to persuade applicants to do a job they didn’t apply for in order to fill that position to meet a number. Very toxic work environment

pros: Nice people, doing good and giving back to the community. The work is rewarding and you can see your impact
cons: Not too many cons, not sure the execs care on the local level. A lot of politics internally but doesn't affect the feeling of giving back and accomplishment.

job_title: Project Lead in San Juan, PR
pros: Its great experience, lots of knowledge
cons: Tough work, could be overwhelming

pros: Amazing place to work alongside passion people with big hearts
cons: N/A great experience during my time there

pros: Restoring healthy homes for clients.
cons: There is no such thing as a work/life balance at SBP. Most staff members are working 7 days/week. Staff members are grossly underpaid. Most locations are understaffed and nothing happens when you bring it up. Quantity over quality mindset. Upper management preaches mental health, open communication, and diversity, but if you bring up an issue, it gets swept under the rug.

review_title: Americorps Members and Staff Treated like dirt
pros: You learn to stand up for yourself
cons:
Toxic Management 
(We were told not to speak to our HR rep, and that if we had a problem with a staff member we needed to work it out with them even if they regularly yelled at or harassed us.)
Racism
(Numerous incidents were reported and swept under the rug for the sake of image.)
Dangerous Work Environment
 (I can’t tell you the number of times AmeriCorps members were put in danger, and we were reprimanded for reporting it. SBP fixes their safety data by over-reporting minor incidents to make it look like major incidents are more rare than they are.) 
Dishonest Staff

pros: Pretty simple job I enjoyed it.
cons: Not enough pay should’ve been a more liveable wage.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: - great mission to the communities served
cons:
- management is very passive aggressive and condescending. 
- if CEO dislikes you, consider your job terminated.  He will do everything in his power to get you to quit. 
- HR department is a joke.  no complaints are ever taken seriously.  no action is taken if there is a proactive or negative morale in the office.  
- if you are ever in a place where you are looking into the deep undertakings of the organization you will find that there is not very many reliable reports that come out of the organization 
- lack of oversight and responsibility of funding and program initiatives  
- open office with no privacy of salaries, hours worked or business of individual clients. 
- the AmeriCorps program is shotty at best.  please consider doing your term somewhere else.  you will be asked to do more than your share of the work that is required.  
- you will only be promoted in the office if you suck up to anyone with "chief" in their title and those titles are created on a whim to suffice development's pitches to funders.

pros: WONDERFUL easy to work with innovative
cons: high paced, lots of moving parts, on the cutting edge of sector

job_title: Project Lead in San Juan, PR
pros: Great organization with a lot of potential and great values.
cons: Due to Covid19, the amount of work done by a Project Lead was very low.

review_title: Excellent Opportunity to Learn New Skills and Help Rebuild Homes After Disaster
pros:
I served as a Site Supervisor for my first term and a Supply and Logistics Coordinator for my second term.  I had no experience in construction or supply/logistics prior to serving my term but received great training in the first few months of joining.

As a site supervisor, leading volunteers in rebuilding was a truly awesome experience.  Volunteers come from all over the country to help SBP rebuild clients' homes and interacting with these groups was always a pleasure.  The greatest experience was attending "Welcome Home Parties" for our clients after their homes were complete.  

As a Supply and Logistics Coordinator, I learned a ton about procurement and ordering as well as tool maintenance.  I also learned how to get building permits and call for building inspections from the city.  Serving in this position provided me a great education in some of the "behind the scenes" operations that are necessary in the construction industry.
cons: The only real challenge for me was initially adjusting to the AmeriCorps living stipend.  Members receive a monthly living stipend of $1,253 which is taxed.   However, I was able to receive about $200 a month in SNAP benefits because I was serving in AmeriCorps.  After some budgeting (which I wasn't great at prior to my term), I was able to make the stipend work for me.  I also earned an Education Award of $5,730 for each one of my completed terms which I used to pay off student loans.

review_title: The McDonald's of Disaster Recovery NPOs
pros: AmeriCorps and middle management are generally wonderful and extremely dedicated. Good place to form friendships and like-minded idealists.
cons:
Upper management/leadership:

- relies too heavily on AmeriCorps members who cycle in/out every 10-12 months for positions that require long-term institutional knowledge. 

- tries to apply a business model that is incompatible with the nature of the work it is attempting to complete. Example: homes are expected to be turned around within timeframes that are ambitious even for well funded, properly staffed, equipped, and trained for-profit construction companies; SBP attempts to match this with unskilled volunteer labor, insufficient/often inexperienced management, and half-broken tools, leading to overworked employees, frustrated volunteers, and shoddy worksmanship on homes in the name of "efficiency"

- seems to care little for its human resources. The organization offered stunningly awful work/life balance for staff and AmeriCorps members (regular 6-day, 60+ hour workweeks) which caused routine burnout and turnover. leadership was not supportive of middle management/Corps members in the slightest, legitimate concerns were ultimately ignored despite repeated promises to change things

- routinely overbooked volunteers, thus causing groups to show up with little to no work to go around and needlessly stressing out volunteer leaders who were trying to provide a positive experience

review_title: Good organization with standard NGO problems
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:
-good mission
-absolutely get to see results of your work, whether it's through seeing a house get built from start to finish, or working with clients who you help to move in. It's nice
-enthusiastic and driven coworkers
-nice building and location
-regular team events like barbecues and welcome home parties. A little too much free cake and donuts, if I am being honest
cons:
-open office plan with very little privacy for the office staff
-management made some strange hiring and firing decisions while I was there, it felt like a constant state of staff shakeup. I think it might have settled since then, though
-only AmeriCorps positions are available for entry level staff! So if you want to get in with SBP, you have to accept being paid less than a full time employee, managing AmeriCorps requirements for hours and behavior, and generally feeling like an intern rather than an employee. However, HR gave us some good support in navigating our AmeriCorps benefits, and provided career advice that could be useful for folks who are just getting started
-if you are good at your job, you will likely be asked to do more than your fair share of work, while other members who are less driven will be allowed to skate by. 
-while most of the staff are former AmeriCorps members, few of the AmeriCorps members get the opportunity to become staff. So there is some opportunity for advancement, but it's competitive and (in my experience) somewhat secretive.

review_title: Great place to work and serve
pros: Being able to make a concrete impact in the lives of people in need.  There are very few jobs out there where you have a tangible results of your hard work.  Not here.  You built a home.  You can see it, walk through it, you can feel the joy it brings to the family you served.  Everyone who does this work does it for the right reasons.  Working with volunteers can be exhausting but they are great people who just want to help.  Constantly challenged, lots of opportunities for growth and new experiences, and you're working for an organization and clients that need you.  Unfortunately, with disasters becoming more frequent and more widespread the organization has grown very quickly and there are lots of opportunities to advance if you work hard, have a positive attitude, and want more responsibility.  Effort and attitude will get you a lot further here than experience.
cons: Not for the faint of heart, the lazy, or the weak willed.  Doing AmeriCorps is challenging no matter what organization you serve in.  If you're in it for the money than you will not be happy.  You have to have a reason and be driven to do this work because it can be physically and mentally exhausting.

job_title: Supply and Logistics Coordinator in Wall Township, NJ
pros: good working environment, good people
cons: closing soon, pay is not great

pros: I absolutely loved my time as an AmeriCorps member especially as a volunteer coordinator with SBP. Everyday I woke up and loved going to work. SBP gives their AmeriCorps members so much responsibility it allows you to grow professionally that when I graduated from my AmeriCorps program I was comfortable to go into a number of fields.  As a volunteer coordinator I got to go out onto site and meet volunteers that I spoke to for months to plan their trip. I got to  watch them fall in love with the work SBP was doing and learned so much from them.  As a volunteer coordinator you get to go out into the field but are mostly office based. The day to day is going out onto site giving the volunteers and orientation then heading into the office to manage the other volunteer groups you have coming. Calling and speaking with different groups all over about their trip, fundraising and getting them excited to work with us!
cons: Any AmeriCorps member will tell you the stipend is the worst part after a month or two you figure out how to use your stipend wisely and budget with what you have. You also are eligible for SNAP food stamps which helps a TON!

job_title: Disaster Recovery in New Orleans, LA
pros: Learn about disaster recovery work
cons: Workload expectations, burn out, turn over

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: This is not the job I want to have forever, but it is a great stepping stone. I graduated from college and had no idea what I was going to do next. Having an opportunity to work in organization that also offers tutorials on grant writing, professional development, and challenges me is great. Since being here I have  done marketing campaigns, become comfortable with yelling at people on the phone, learned the ins and outs of selling a home, and so much more. The people here are great! Cohorts of AmeriCorps members starting at the same time, so you automatically have friends. People move from all over the country to work here- I came from California. It also is a great way to have an adventure- 9 months move to a new city and meet some really cool people.
cons: Lack of half and half for coffee Tight budget- but they tell you about this Be sure to get SNAP (food stamps) they make budgeting so much better It is manageable but don't expect to be saving for your European Trip The movie theater next door makes the parking lot smell like popcorn sometimes

job_title: Client Service Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros:
After graduating college I knew it would be tough to find a job so I joined SBP through AmeriCorps. I was able to work with clients who went through Hurricanes Katrina & Isaac. 
SBP  gives you a ton of opportunity for development, I learned a lot through working with the population I served. AmC members were also able to "deploy" for a month or two when other disasters occurred.
The people that join SBP (AmC & staff) are really cool and service minded, I met some of the best people while working at SBP.
cons:
The funding was starting to dwindle for Katrina projects which was difficult at times to explain to homeowners who still weren't home, but it made the team get creative with fundraising.
The work can be difficult and emotional but ultimately worth it. 
AmC stipend can be challenging but with food stamps and budgeting it is definitely doable.

pros: Americorps members are great, hardworking and intelligent for the most part. Your experience really depends on your own attitude and what you're willing to put into it.
cons: Corporate management hires the least skilled, experienced individuals for supervisor/management positions.  Rather than hiring qualified candidates that will work hard and think for themselves, they resort to the most impressionable and least independent thinkers for managerial positions in order to promote their own agenda.  On multiple occasions hiring decisions have been made to offer management/director positions to individuals with absolutely no job experience outside of serving as an Americorps member, over legitimately qualified and experienced people.

review_title: Great people, little incentive to stay long-term
pros:
-The people who work here have the biggest hearts and a lot of great energy to support the mission
-Upon proving yourself, there is opportunity for you to take on managerial roles with greater responsibilities, which is unique for young professionals seeking a higher degree of career development
cons:
-Quantity over quality homes

-Turnover is very high:
   -the demands on employees are extreme and the pay is low, leading most employees to burn out
   -the more experienced individuals cycle out frequently, thus the quality and content of training provided to new staff is constantly changing
   -frequently reinventing the wheel: new employees with lots of energy have the desire to improve daily functions and solutions. However, previous employees have already tried to implement similar improvements while long-term support and follow-through from management does not exist.

-Top leadership conveys a sense of approachability, team unity, and willingness to problem solve the organization's areas of improvement. However, it is easy to hit a nerve (for example, advocating higher quality materials) and you will quickly find yourself on the outside.

review_title: Challenging but rewarding place to work
pros:
I was an AmeriCorps member and staff member with SBP.
-neither position was easy but there was help when I asked for it
- you're pushed and challenged as most of our money goes into AmeriCorps members and building homes instead of bringing on more staff
- the work we did was so meaningful and the team members that we brought on were generally amazing. I found that the ones that didn't do well, weren't used to being given a lot of responsibility and independence.
- opportunities for growth and development
cons:
- long hours and lots of hard work
- the work can be very emotional, you're helping clients rebuild after a disaster
- as an AmeriCorps member, you're in a program that doesn't pay a lot which can add more stress

review_title: Shoddy Houses, Shady Business Dealings, Very bad reputation in New Orleans
pros:
Lots of staff- they have a new facility now that looks nice. 
They will literally hire anyone (pro and con but good for people with no work or education experience) 
If the CEO takes a liking to you, you may be able to move into a staff position.
cons: SBP tries really hard to be different and innovative , but behind the glittery TED talk-esque performances  of upper managements the " innovations" they  so boldly and proudly exclaim are just elaborate double-speak for building shoddy houses, mistreating and screwing over their clients, and overworking and underpaying all their employees.  This is not a new way of doing business, this is simply a reiteration of the good ol fashioned traveling show of a snake oil salesman. Proclaiming salvation in one hand while deliberately taking advantage of the community in the other- all in a narcissistic and self interested pursuit of supposedly charitable activities.

review_title: Incredible experience within an organization continually growing
job_title: Volunteer Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: The AmeriCorps program adds so much to an organization. By grouping young and old individuals with a passion together, the workforce is competitive and a great foundation for a smaller non-profit. The people in the program are amazing and a huge pro to being part of SBP. On top of that, the work itself is never boring. There's always something happening and you are constantly working. Make sure you know you're getting into a low-paying position that will require a lot from you. If you understand that, you'll be good to go.
cons: Upper management definitely has some kinks to work out, specifically how they communicate with the AmeriCorps member. The majority of them are truly wonderful people, but some of the very high ups need to relate better to those working for them.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: Fellow AmeriCorps members and immediate supervisors very passionate and down to earth, the work is very rewarding and most of the clients we worked with were inspiring. They trust you with a lot of responsibility fairly quickly and encourage you to always be thinking of ways to improve how things are done.
cons: Senior management made effort to be approachable, but on a day to day basis I rarely felt like they would be able to make time for me, unless I had a serious problem. Although, they did host a full team meeting which helped. Also, towards the end of my term, a few of my coworkers had pretty negative experiences with senior management.

pros: Countless opportunities to learn new skills. Nice to meet some many families and clients that one's Americorps term is contributing towards. The day-to-day with co-workers is fun and empowering.
cons: There is a very noticeable air of unhappiness and jadedness that occurs throughout one's term. Americorps members often feel undervalued and the organization's reaction typically involves forced clapping and appreciation, rather than measurable actions that make members feel genuinely valued. There seems to be considerable feelings of disconnect between upper level management and Americorps members. At times I felt insecure about expressing my frustrations for fear of ostrization from higher ups.

pros: The work is super rewarding and everyone you work alongside of is there for the same reason: to help other people. Loved getting to go to work and make the lives of others better through what I did each and every day. Getting to do so alongside of people that I genuinely enjoyed was a plus as well.
cons: The work is demanding and stressful which coupled with limited pay, leads to a lot of turnover. Also, the nature of volunteer/funder driven service can lead to a lot of last-minute curve balls and change-ups. Definitely have to be flexible enough to think on your feet and juggle multiple things of varying priorities.

job_title: Construction Site Supervisor in Chalmette, LA
pros: As an AmeriCorps site supervisor I worked directly with the agency's volunteers to rebuild our clients' homes. I met some amazing clients, volunteers, and AmeriCorps peers, and that made the experience worthwhile.
cons: I found the organization to be poorly organized. Most of the site supervisors weren't sufficiently trained to perform our job duties. There was a lot of wasted labor and materials. I was exposed to numerous harmful chemicals and materials and when I spoke up about this I was bullied by the construction director. My construction manager was a joke. He didn't have a clue what he was doing and favored attractive young women. The upper management treated field staff with dismissive condescension.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros:
The best part about working at SBP was meeting amazingly gifted and dedicated AmeriCorps members, staff and members of the community. I gained a lot of skills and grew a lot from this experience. You get to learn a lot about an amazing community and an important city (if you're in New Orleans). The managers work their butts off day in and day out, and can be incredibly motivating people.

There is already a great culture of "constructive discontent," which allows you to feel comfortable and supported when solvable problems do arise. Whenever management is available, they do their best to help navigate issues that arise in the organization.

I don't think that anyone here has malicious intent or is in it for the wrong reasons. I just think there is a lack of understanding and a willing ignorance to the problems that arise, along with a secretive facade that they show to the world (particularly volunteers and sponsors). A lot of the cons that I'll elaborate on could be fixed if upper and middle management were given a little less work and a lot more praise, and the lines of communication were more open and transparent.
cons:
One of the biggest challenges was the incredible lack of professionalism. From the get go, everyone is invited into a very lax culture of drinking and hanging out as a team. Superficially this seemed great! However, it quickly became apparent that this same attitude is applied to the organizational and management structure of the entire operation. Managers frequently fraternize with AmeriCorps members, giving them unfair opportunities and making conflict resolution nearly impossible (especially with non-existent HR staff.) 

Upper management rarely listens to the needs of AmeriCorps members, particularly those who work in the field, who are often expected to work over 60 hours a week, including weekends, when other AmeriCorps members had more flexible scheduling. Even during my time there, I felt like some things were dealt with, only to find out that as soon as the people who were complaining about a certain thing left, it went back to the way it was before. Incredible lack of institutional memory. 

There was also a clear divide in opportunities between those who worked in the field and those who worked in the office. A majority of the staff who works there full time now were once AmeriCorps office members, and only two or three were in the field. 

There is no warehouse manager, which made the poor warehouse team work themselves to death in order to keep up inventory and orders to move houses along. 

Client service coordinators are expected to do intense social work type jobs, but are rarely certified or trained to do such work, causing some unhappy homeowners and coordinators in a delicate situation. It can be emotionally taxing on the Client Service Coordinator, which makes their job more difficult. Volunteer coordinators have become money grubbers. As much as they would love to spend more time with the volunteers that come through SBP, they are expected to raise a certain amount of money and convert volunteers (who have already spent so much time and money in order to travel in the first place) into donors. They have little to no interaction with them otherwise.  Construction Coordinators are thrown into the pit and expected to be able to pull all sorts of permits and schedule pretty much the entire housing board with little to no training in the beginning. 

There are not enough Project Managers. The ones already there are fantastic, but get bogged down and so busy with the amount of houses, there's little to no time to develop site supervisors (which is a part of their job) so they rely on second term AmeriCorps members to pick up the slack. Second term members are also offered wonderful opportunities and benefits, just so they sign up for another term. But once the term is actually started, a lot of those benefits are never seen. I saw many incredibly talented AmeriCorps members leave with such a bitter taste because of these false promises. They spent countless hours improving the organization and in the end all of their efforts were tossed aside.

There was little to no feedback about the work that you did do, positive or negative, so it felt like there was no room for growth.

On top of all of this was the incredible lack of concern for staff member's safety (particularly in the field). As a rebuilding organization in one of the oldest cities in North America, they only recently came up with a lead safety protocol to protect their volunteers and staff. There were multiple times that framers were sent in to do demo on houses that had clear asbestos safety concerns, but we're not informed of the dangers. No one on the staff is OSHA certified, and they have a very lax attitude towards mold remediation protocols.

Another problem was the idea that SBP has a significant role to play in hiring Veterans or members of Good Work Good Pay (working with v. The amount of trainings for Good Work Good Pay are inconsistent and the members involved are not guaranteed a job afterwards (although are promised such things). Also, the preference of Veteran hiring is not as a part of what they call Veteran Corps, and they do little to nothing in terms of extra benefits or after SBP help/care for these particular individuals. These were simply used as tools to prove to the community that SBP “hires locals” when in fact, most of our work force are recent college graduates from the Northeast.

There are a lot of secretive things going on, and a lot of misunderstanding about where the money goes towards, particularly since we have previous received funding and assistance from MAJOR global corporations such as Goldman-Sachs, Dow Chemical, Toyota, UPS, Shell, etc. They have even needed to use volunteers to help finish the new building, so where is the money going? They also claim that each house costs $25,000 in volunteer donations... when it is a perfectly legitimate thing to say, volunteer donations goes into a pool to cover operational costs of the organization.

pros: The people you work with are amazing - Americorps and staff. Young, idealistic, smart, motivated. Want to make an impact in the community.
cons:
Issues stem from the top, seeming to originate from a "it's worked so far mindset." 

There is much talk about change and best practices, but these changes are usually in word/policy only. Changes that cost money (hiring more staff, upgrading fleet) are often ignored or taken as a unforgivable breach of trust.

review_title: More like a business, less like a nonprofit.
job_title: Site Supervisor (Americorps Position) in New Orleans, LA
pros: Learning construction skills was certainly the best part of the position. If the leadership in the organization favors you, you will easily be able to move up within the organization if you choose to stay with them. They are also very generous with supporting you into whatever your next move is.
cons: The leadership is narrow-minded and not very open to constructive criticism (although one of the preached values is 'constructive discontent'). The management is very young and not always the most professional. They are learning though.

pros: SBP is a nonprofit disaster relief organization which leverages Americorps members and volunteers to help return affected families to their homes. In Rockaway, NYC, where I served, the organization was serving one of the areas hit worst by hurricane Sandy. As a n Ameriorps member the pay was minimal (government stipend) but the experience was fulfilling and heartwarming.
cons: SBP asks a lot from its employees, as they are understaffed and underfunded. Often times organization for day to day activities was lacking, though that is changing for the better.

review_title: Do your AmeriCorps term somewhere else
pros: Gained valuable work experience, helped people
cons: Constantly trying to get around AmeriCorps member protections  - exploitative and manipulative to the extreme. They're constantly under investigation by CNCS (governing body for AmeriCorps) because they are AWFUL to members. There's a lot of staff overturn so they must be pretty bad to staff, too. You will be expected to break the rules and take on way more than you're supposed to, and because most AmeriCorps members are young and inexperienced, they will bank on your ignorance to try and scare you into silence. You can get valuable experience at a way better nonprofit that will treat you better.

review_title: Organization with a Great Heart and Ambitious Goals
pros:
I get to spend my energy doing something that helps people in need.
Getting to know  so many AmeriCorps members! They are certainly the best individduals I have  met in a long time. Such big hearts and dedication!
Constantly striving to work more efficiently and to shorten the time between disaster and recovery for people in need.
This is a job that gives great satisfaction that at the end of each day, I have done something that really matters.
cons: That the AmreiCorps members and staff do not get the national recognition they deserve.

pros: I've made some of my best friends here. Everyone is incredibly kind, and I have met really amazing people. I was able to get valuable experience and learn how on-profits work - I will always be grateful for the things I've learned with SBP!
cons: With 10 month terms, a lot of your work friends will come and go. The pay can be difficult to handle - but everyone going in to it knows exactly how much they will be making so there's really no reason to be surprised!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Far Rockaway, NY
pros: SBP offers opportunities to members that have little-to-no experience entering into their terms of service. Starting as a Site Supervisor, you are trained in every stage of construction from the beginning. The experience is absolutely challenging and flexibility and adaptability are incredibly important, but it is truly rewarding.  If you believe in getting people back home after a disaster occurs, then this is the organization for you.
cons: The AmeriCorps stipend was very challenging to live off of. If you ask for help and guidance, then you can find ways to supplement the stipend with food stamps, loan forbearance, possible part-time work, etc.

pros: The people you meet while working at SBP as well as working as an Americorps member are very smart and capable. There is a feeling of immense reward when you teach Americorps members construction tasks as well as when a homeowner is finally brought home.
cons: The management there is the only real problem, I found it to be a toxic work environment. I had a very poor working relationship with my managers even though I was putting my all into my work; I know I was undrrexpereinced for the role but I felt that this was used as leverage against me all the time.

review_title: Unparalleled opportunity for dedicated employees...at a cost
pros:
I write this from the perspective as a staff member, not an AmeriCorps member like nearly every other review.  While that is indeed an important perspective, it doesn't speak to what it is like as a manager.

SBP is a place where individuals who work hard and are willing to play the game a bit are given near limitless opportunity to grow within the organization and take on new responsibilities.

Generally the results speak for themselves.  In NOLA, SBP has rebuilt more homes than any other group.  SBP has been a leader in Sandy recovery in NYC.  In New Jersey, SBP is opening up shop when other groups are closing down.  That's an infectious environment to work within.

As others have said, the people are a huge asset to SBP.  Disaster work is hard and the management team is very close-knit.

SBP's leadership & vision are top notch.  I think Zack Rosenburg has been excellent at positioning SBP for national prominence.  The fact that SBP is still building homes in New Orleans 10 years after Katrina speaks for itself.  Zack can be a bit of a jerk but he is SBP's jerk.  He relentlessly promotes SBP and is quite the pitch man.  Frankly, I'm glad he helms the organization.  I know this is an unpopular opinion to hold at SBP.  With all this said, his management and operational skills have room for growth.
cons:
Zack's managerial skills.  While a great pitch man, visionary, and strategist, he is not a good manager and struggles to effectively manage operations at affiliates.

Fast growth without infrastructure or well-defined processes.  SBP grew from operating from one location to operating in 4-5 locations very quickly.  There are few (if any) staff members dedicated to overseeing or structuring national operations.  Each operation is an island with the CEO blindly calling the shots from New Orleans.

Unhealthy work-life balance.  At SBP's upper levels, employees are expected to pull 80 hour work weeks.  While the vacation policy is reasonable, most employees see their vacation days expire each year because the culture discourages stepping away from work.

pros: The group is doing a great service to the people that are affected, and you will meet some amazing people.
cons: The leaders of the place will work you until you are drained of life, and then insult you on the way out the door.  Also, with all the needs for disaster recovery in the world, I felt sometimes like they keep the organization going just to keep getting paid.

review_title: Rewarding experience where you can see the direct impact you are making in the community.
pros: People work here because they want to, which means they are productive and don't try to undermine each other. People behave much differently when they view work as a calling and they can see the good they are doing in the world. People don't chase bonuses or promotions here, which makes everyone a lot less stressed and more genuine.
cons: Full-time workload with some overtime expected for little pay as an Americorps member ($1,500/month stipend). You are expected to work at least two Saturday's every month.

job_title: Client Services Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: I met some great people at SBP.  A couple still work there; most do not.
cons: While working here, I spent ten months taking applications from people and meeting community members in need of assistance to do repairs on their home. I did not see ONE of those applicants have any repairs done on their house. Management was not even a little concerned about this - in fact, at the time they were building a fancy new building & rapidly gentrifying the area.

pros: Great community. Great people. Lots of opportunities to move around the company (and the country) as you find things that interest you.
cons: Does not pay very much...it was an AmeriCorps position so this was expected. Sometimes disorganized but thats the nature of non-profits..and led to plenty of room for growth.

pros:
I  enjoy working in an office setting and gaining transferable skills for my future, but also having opportunities to get out of the office to visit sites and attend outreach events. 

There is no such thing as a normal day in my role, and it's never boring. I get to work on many different projects while gaining insight and skills in various areas.  

I am fortunate to be working under one of the best managers I've ever had, and there are so many supportive staff members  on the team. 

There are frequently events that make AmeriCorps members feel valued. There's a great social culture because AmeriCorps members start in cohorts.

Many of our team members have moved from all over the country, myself included. SBP's AmeriCorps program is a great opportunity to live somewhere new alongside others who are in the same situation and with the comfort of knowing it only has to be for 5 or 10 months. 

The work of SBP matters. Every day is rewarding. You get to be surrounded by other AmeriCorps members, staff, and volunteers who believe in the mission. You also get to see tangible results and know you're helping an entire community.
cons:
The majority of the negative things I could say about SBP would be true of any AmeriCorps/service year position. The stipend is tight, but very doable - especially in a place like New Orleans.  Serving 1,700 hours in 10 months translates to spending a lot of your time in service, and the roles are challenging. 

No organization is perfect, so SBP does have room to grow. My biggest complaint is the need for improved communication within the organization. However, SBP recognizes this need to improve and is actively seeking feedback from employees/AmeriCorps members and working to implement change.

pros: This organization runs like a business and cares about people (SBP team members and the families we serve). The work is challenging, ideas are welcome, we talk about problems. Most people who thrive at SBP are the people who are internally driven and who are their own worst critics. SBP is a growing organization and it's exciting to be on the team.
cons: Fast pace and unpredictability is the name of the game in the disaster recovery world.

review_title: Look for other options before you decide to join SBP
pros: I had a chance to meet a lot of amazing people.
cons: Over time SBP started to become less about the people and more about the CEO and his agenda to make SBP a well known company. We were considered free labor. Since we were only around for 10 months at a time, upper management did not take our complaints or suggestions seriously.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: The other Americorps members you'll meet serving as an Americorps member yourself will be a really awesome experience.
cons:
If you make the mistake of serving here, prepare to find the things about your specific area of focus that interest you (and ultimately make you happy) and zero in on those aspects on your own as you'll get no guidance or encouragement from staff and managers who are either actively two-faced or too busy pushing through the organization's branding agenda to teach and mentor you as an Americorps member. If you're lucky enough to serve in the field as a site supervisor you *may*, you *MAY*, see real results from your efforts but, a majority of the time, you'll quickly realize managerial incompetence or exhaustion and institutional disorganization derails most projects in which you will take part. On that note and amongst a host of others, you'll find that the clients, families, and communities that SBP supposedly serves are merely props for furthering SBP's brand. Building homes and bringing families home are incidental to the organization's day-to-day work: feeding SBP's marketing machine and brand recognition.

If you can put these things out of your mind while also taking into account that you will be treated not as service members but rather a completely free workforce and in that way digest and internalize the fact that SBP will not and doesn't care about your experience, comfort, or well-being but instead needs to wring 10 months of completely free labor out of you by any means necessary you might get through your term without resigning.

Be careful not to fall for the seemingly kind words from upper, upper management. They will promise to hire you after your term as well as write letters of recommendation and help you with your career when you graduate. None of this will happen. You won't even get a Microsoft Office template letter of recommendation printed on basic white paper with their signature.

I would not recommend this organization for donations or volunteer opportunities. There are others if you do a bit a research and digging and your heart is open to helping.

pros: The people, AmeriCorps and staff, are the best.  You won't find a greater group of workers to work with and around.
cons: The "Upper" management doesn't know how to lead the company, turnover is out of control, everyone is unhappy, the AmeriCorps members are overworked, most of the staff is overworked and underpaid.

review_title: Negative work environment for AmeriCorps members and full-time staffers; very high turnover rate indicates big problems
pros:
-Rebuilding organization with clear impact on the community
-Lots of young AmeriCorps volunteers = fun environment for new grad workers
cons:
-Managers lacked experience in many depts
-Work environment was negative and staff retention is very low (example: 3 finance directors cycled through in 2 years)
-Some program directors don't have the training for positions they're placed in (example: 'HR' personnel with no training in the field for a staff of nearly 100)
-Over-reliance on AmeriCorps means no continuity in most depts (example: some clients cycled through 3 or 4 case managers in less than 2 years)

review_title: Draining Work Environment, Lack of Support for Americorps/Employees
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Orleans, LA
pros: While support is minimal, and there are questionable things occurring, you are able to learn new skills and at the end of the day, you are helping those in need by repairing/rebuilding their homes. Other Americorps and most staff are also some of the most caring, down-to-earth people you will meet and you will form strong bonds with those you connect with.
cons:
As an Americorps member, it's common to feel highly undervalued. We make up most of the "employees" but it is clear to them how dispensable we are. Upper management will try and disguise this with a slew of insincere compliments. It is hard work,  and that is something known when agreeing to be an Americorps member, but you are offered little to no support. Most staff are very kind people and WANT to help, but are not given the training, support, or resources themselves to do so by upper management. For instance, there are not enough Project Managers, and while the current team is great, they are severely overloaded and not able to commit time to certain aspects of their job (such as training Site Supervisors) and other details get overlooked, only for them to get unfair lectures and criticisms from those that run the organization. The higher-ups seem completely satisfied with the understaffing in every department that results in everyone having a completely obliterated morale from being overworked and trying to keep up with their demands. 

Staff and Americorps members are continually treated with disdain and disrespect from the highest levels, which only serves to enforce the "trapped" feelings and jadedness in the workplace. Anyone that tries to voice their opinion/complaints is often dismissed.


There is also a lot of secretive, questionable, and misleading information regarding funding, how it is sourced, and where donations actually go/how that money is used. A lot of false promises are made to clients on the behalf of higher management, often leaving Client Services Coordinators in extremely difficult situations for which they must bear the emotional burden.

Working here will leave you feeling unnaturally drained and burnt-out. Upper management will provide faux-comfort or attempt to convince you this is "professional development," but not actually do anything to change the circumstances. There is a trickle-down effect that ultimately creates a very negative and exhausting work environment.

job_title: Volunteer Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros:
Good people
Able to learn new skills without experience 
Stepping stone experience 
Amazing clients - amazing stories
cons:
Heavy focus on funding initiatives 
VC manager made work difficult 
Heavy workload
Very disorganized

pros:
- Encouraging Environment
-Afforded the ability to take risks, and learn from failure
-Org is completely malleable, able to influence change and leave a mark
cons:
-Demanding work, emotionally, physically, and mentally taxing at times
-Life/work balance is a bit heavy on the work side

pros: New people so committed and idealistic
cons: Corrupt leadership to the core. Owners make 500K a year just on one of their nonprofits.  Boiler room environment and all about $$$ BEWARE Smoke and Mirrors!!

review_title: Signed on for the mission, saw the organization miss the mark in nyc because of poor leadership. It was disappointing.
pros: Some great coworkers, good work gets completed sometimes.  Again the mission is great but the execution in nyc has been underwhelming.
cons: Not enough middle management, upper management is inexperienced and it's clear they don't know what they're doing. Departments all working in their own bubble.

job_title: Project Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros: The clients and bringing people home
cons: Senior management does not value construction staff which is ironic, given what they do. They work you to the bone and then insult you on your way out the door.

pros: I had a good time working here and learned a lot also got a grant for college.
cons: there were not a lot of cons.  I knew the length and time I was signing up for when I started.

pros: Opportunity to work within the community and help families impacted by hurricane Harvey.
cons: Discriminatory and stressful Workplace. No credit given to the deserving.  Lots of lies surfacing. People in positions they should not be.  More so a hustle than a nonprofit. Not to mention all of the thieving that goes on.  No real values.

job_title: Client Service Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: They help with your resume and jobs after SBP.
cons: The pay and separation between staff and AmeriCorps members.

job_title: Client Service Coordinator in New Orleans, LA
pros: SBP has a very genuine and supportive office environment. There are always ways to expand past your current role.
cons: Operating under CNO may take some patience in between grants.

review_title: Lots of great people in this mission focused organization
pros: Team works hard, spirit of social entrepreneurship, providing much needed services for the community
cons: Can't always accept all the volunteers who want to help

pros:
Work with passionate coworkers
Room for growth
Promote from within 
Great cause
cons:
Long hrs
Low pay/living stipend 
Lack of experienced staff
Poor interdepartmental communication

pros: nature of work is the best thing
cons: late sittings and work on weekdays

pros: Program is ever growing creating great improvements with it. More efficiency and predictability for clients
cons: turn over can create gaps in departmental need

pros: Great cause helping great people.
cons: Upper management doesn't always address concerns or make next steps clear.

pros: Freedom to explore ideas you bring to the table. Wonderful organization helping people in need.
cons: None, this was a great job!

pros:
community involvement
be a part of the rebuilding process 
great professional experience for resume
cons:
living stipend as pay
unpredictable work environment

pros: Great Place to work and meet people
cons: Quiet place with no communication

pros: love the learning experience since ive started.
